Since before his first presidency, Trump has promoted numerous conspiracy theories, including Obama "birtherism", climate change denial, and alleged Ukrainian interference in U.S. elections.[688][689][690] After the 2020 presidential election, he promoted conspiracy theories for his defeat that were characterized as "the big lie".[691][692]

False or misleading statements

Trump frequently makes false statements in public remarks,[696][146] to an extent unprecedented in American politics.[696][697][698] His falsehoods are a distinctive part of his political identity[697] and have been described as firehosing. His false and misleading statements were documented by fact-checkers, including at The Washington Post, which tallied 30,573 false or misleading statements made by him during his first presidency,[693] increasing in frequency over time.[700]

Some of Trump's falsehoods were inconsequential,[701][702] while others had more far-reaching effects, such as his unproven promotion of antimalarial drugs as a treatment for COVID-19,[703][704] causing a U.S. shortage of these drugs and panic-buying in Africa and South Asia.[705][706] Other misinformation, such as misattributing a rise in crime in England and Wales to the "spread of radical Islamic terror", served his domestic political purposes.[707] His attacks on mail-in ballots and other election practices weakened public faith in the integrity of the 2020 presidential election,[708][709] while his disinformation about the pandemic delayed and weakened the national response to it.[710][711][712] He habitually does not apologize for his falsehoods.[713] Until 2018, the media rarely referred to his falsehoods as lies, including when he repeated demonstrably false statements.[714][715][716]

Social media

Trump's social media presence attracted worldwide attention after he joined Twitter in 2009. He posted frequently during his 2016 campaign and as president until Twitter banned him after the January 6 attack.[717] He often used Twitter to communicate directly with the public and sideline the press;[718] in 2017, his press secretary said that his tweets constituted official presidential statements.[719] During his 2024 campaign and second presidency he frequently posted AI-generated content of himself as pop-culture icons or mocking immigrants.[720][721]

After years of criticism for allowing Trump to post misinformation and falsehoods, Twitter began to tag some of his tweets with fact-checks in May 2020.[722] In response, he said social media platforms "totally silence" conservatives and he would "strongly regulate, or close them down".[723] After the January 6 attack, he was banned from Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and other platforms.[724] The loss of his social media presence diminished his ability to shape events[725][726] and correlated with a dramatic decrease in the volume of misinformation on Twitter.[727] In February 2022, he launched social media platform Truth Social where he attracted a fraction of his Twitter following.[728] Elon Musk, after acquiring Twitter, reinstated his Twitter account in November 2022.[729][730] The two-year ban at Meta Platforms lapsed in January 2023, allowing him to return to Facebook and Instagram.[731]

Relationship with the press

Talking to the press, March 2017

Trump sought media attention throughout his career, maintaining a "love-hate" relationship with the press.[732] In the 2016 campaign, he benefited from a record amount of free media coverage,[733] estimated at $2 billion.[734] As a candidate and as president, he frequently accused the press of bias, calling it the "fake news media" and "the enemy of the people".[735]

The first Trump presidency reduced formal press briefings from about one hundred in 2017 to about half that in 2018 and to two in 2019. They also revoked the press passes of two White House reporters, which were restored by the courts.[736] His 2020 presidential campaign sued The New York Times, The Washington Post, and CNN for defamation in opinion pieces about his stance on Russian election interference. All the suits were dismissed.[737][738] By 2024, he repeatedly voiced support for outlawing political dissent and criticism,[739] and said that reporters should be prosecuted for not divulging confidential sources and media companies should possibly lose their broadcast licenses for unfavorable coverage of him.[740]

In his second term, Trump's actions against the media were unprecedented in modern American history,[741] and historians described them as mirroring actions by authoritarian leaders to censor political opponents and negatively impacting the freedom of speech and free press.[742][743] The campaign to police speech drew comparisons to cancel culture, government censorship, and McCarthyism.[744][745][746] Some were sued and many social media companies,[747] broadcasters, and newspapers capitulated to the Trump agenda.[748] Trump launched lawsuits and created blacklists against certain media outlets, took over the process run by the White House Correspondents' Association to choose what outlets have access to him and made a policy of limited access for all wire services.[749][750] The Federal Communications Commission launched investigations into media outlets accused of bias against him.[751] As a result of Trump's threats, media executives instructed journalists and their staff to self-censor and reduce criticism of Trump,[752] and CBS agreed to create an Ombudsman to monitor its news channels to root out "bias" at CBS News.[753]

Personal life

Family

In 1977, Trump married Ivana Zelníčková. They had three children: Donald Jr. (b. 1977), Ivanka (b. 1981), and Eric (b. 1984). The couple divorced in 1990, following his affair with model and actress Marla Maples.[755] He and Maples married in 1993 and divorced in 1999. They have one daughter, Tiffany (b. 1993), whom Maples raised in California.[756] In 2005, he married Slovenian model Melania Knauss. They have one son, Barron (b. 2006).[758]

Relationship with Jeffrey Epstein

Trump had a 15-year friendship with Jeffrey Epstein. Persons who knew them at the time said they frequently hit on and competed for women.[759] Media attention and public pressure mounted in 2025, when his administration did not release files relating to Epstein, despite Trump's promise to do so during the 2024 campaign.[760]

Health

Trump says he has never drunk alcohol, smoked cigarettes, or used drugs,[761][762] and that he sleeps about four or five hours a night.[763] He has called golfing his "primary form of exercise", but usually does not walk the course.[765] Trump considers exercise a waste of energy as he believes the body is "like a battery, with a finite amount of energy", which is depleted by exercise.[766]

In 2015, his campaign released a letter from his longtime personal physician, Harold Bornstein, stating that he would "be the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency".[768] In 2018, Bornstein said Trump had dictated the contents of the letter and that three of Trump's agents had seized his medical records in a February 2017 raid on Bornstein's office.[768][769]

Religion

Trump called himself a Presbyterian and a Protestant in 2016.[770][771] In 2020, he said he was a nondenominational Christian.[772] However, many have questioned the depth of these religious affiliations. A survey during his first presidency (2017–2021) showed that 63 percent of Americans did not believe that he was religious, despite professing a Christian affiliation, and that only 44 percent of Americans believed Trump was a Christian.[773] Some of Trump's comments on the Bible or Christian practice have led critical observers to suggest that his knowledge of Christianity is superficial or erroneous, and few biographers have described him as deeply or even particularly religious.[774][775]

In his first term, Trump appointed his personal pastor[776] and spiritual advisor,[777] millionaire televangelist Paula White-Cain, to the White House Office of Public Liaison.[778] During his second term, he appointed her senior advisor of the newly created White House Faith Office.[779][780]

Assessments

Public image

In Trump's first term, from 2017 to 2021, international approval ratings of U.S. leadership dropped from about 22 percent in a Gallup poll[781] of 134 countries to just 16 percent—lower than China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin—in a Pew Research poll[782] of 13 countries. In 2017, estimation of U.S. leadership declined most among allies.[783]

Domestically, in his first term, Trump had chiefly partisan support: 88 percent among Republicans and 7 percent among Democrats.[784] In a 2021 Gallup poll, he was the only president never to reach a 50 percent approval rating, and he was the first not to be named most admired in his first year in office.[785]

In his second term's first quarter according to Gallup, Trump's approval rating was 45 percent—somewhat better than his first term, and far below the 60 percent average of other presidents. Support remained polarized; he had the approval of 90 percent among Republicans, 37 percent among independents, and 4 percent among Democrats.[786] His second term also saw large drops in global public opinion of the United States.[787]

Scholarly rankings

After Trump's first term, historians ranked Trump as the fourth-worst president in C-SPAN's 2021 survey of presidential historians.[788] He rated lowest in the leadership characteristics categories for moral authority and administrative skills.[789][790] The Siena College Research Institute's 2022 survey ranked him third-worst. He was ranked near the bottom in all categories except for luck, willingness to take risks, and party leadership, and ranked last in several categories.[791] In 2018 and 2024, members of the American Political Science Association ranked him the worst president.[792][793]
